Yes, this really did start with a friend asking me if I’d be interested in joining ChangeMakeHer as a chief ambassador – a small conversation sparked so much more.

I’m a Teen Running a Company That Helps Girls to Choose STEM. Here’s What That’s Like.

“Hey Jeanette, would you like to run a company?”

Jeanette Hodgson
Mar 30

Yes, this really did start with a friend asking me if I’d be interested in joining ChangeMakeHer as a chief ambassador – a small conversation sparked so much more.

Although I’d heard of ChangeMakeHer – as a girl in the school where it was founded, this was unavoidable – I had never been to one of their meetings or events. To say I was surprised at the prospect of taking over the organisation this year would be an understatement.

It seemed like such a huge opportunity – and I honestly knew I did not have time to take it on. But I was so determined to do it: female empowerment is something I am so passionate about, and I felt like the sacrifices I would make to run the ChangeMakeHer events and programs would be worth it, even if it only directly empowered a few young girls.

So, along with a long-time friend, I took on the role.

For a bit of context, ChangeMakeHer is an organisation founded by two high school students. Every year, the role of Chief Ambassador (which is similar to CEO, I guess) rotates through to a new pair of students in their final year of school. Last year’s ambassadors made some great strides with the organisation, and even organised a TEDx event in our city from the ground-up in their spare time – 0t’s going to be very difficult to rival what they did last year.

However, my friend and I are up to the challenge, and very excited to see what we can do within the role this year! Our mission is to increase diversity in the Australian workforce, by inspiring, empowering, and equipping Australia’s young women to change the world. We run events for high school girls to explore careers in STEM, and connect with successful women. But, why is this so important?

Well, according to the Foundation for Young Australians, women only account for 16% of Australia’s STEM fields. This is for a variety of reasons, one of which is the barriers placed in the way of girls from a very young age. This is a huge problem, as scientific, technological and engineering projects will likely take place without female input, meaning that new creations will only cater to the needs of a specific demographic: men.

For example, the first generation of airbags for cars used adult male bodies as the basis for their designs, which resulted in many unnecessary deaths of women and children. What’s more, women are squeezed out of STEM careers or discouraged from entering the field in the first place, whether this be in the early stages of their life, or later on, perhaps when they study at university.

ChangeMakeHer believes that it’s important to target girls as soon as possible and expose them to the STEM career pathways available, and teach them skills they’ll need to thrive in their future studies and jobs.

Personally, I’ve found the first few weeks as Chief Ambassador incredibly challenging, but also incredibly rewarding. Being completely new to organising finances, marketing and communications, it’s been a massive learning journey for me – I knew some of the more basic things, but it’s been a challenge to ensure that I’m doing stuff correctly. I honestly never knew that graphic design was so time consuming until I tried to make an information pack – although I don’t think my dinosaur laptop really helped!

But at the same time, knowing that the programs we’re launching have the potential to help someone, or many someones, is so inspiring, and motivates me to keep working. At the end of the day, if one girl walks away from one of our events and feels empowered, it’s worth all the tears, anxious breakdowns, email and time that it took to ensure that she felt that way.

Honestly, I don’t think 10 year old me would have ever pictured 16 year old me running an organisation designed to empower other high school girls, but I’m so glad that I am. Despite the constant stress of balancing this with school work and other commitments, it’s honestly the most rewarding thing ever (both in terms of personal development and social impact).

Jeanette is a regular columnist for the Minds in Tune blog. She likes to write about study and travel. When she’s not writing for us — or working for ChangeMakeHer — she can be found managing her study-focused Instagram account: @jeanettestudies, as well as her YouTube channel.

Keep up with the blog to read more of Jeanette’s articles, and catch new episodes of Minds in Tune every Saturday in your preferred podcast app. For more Minds in Tune content, check out our posts from @mindsintune on most social media platforms.

You can find out more about ChangeMakeHer here.
